required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Maintaining Optimal Trauma Outcomes: Resilience in the Midst of a Ransomware Attack
clinical_study.official_title: Maintaining Optimal Trauma Outcomes: Resilience in the Midst of a Ransomware Attack

lead_sponsor.agency: State University of New York at Buffalo

clinical_study.source: State University of New York at Buffalo

brief_summary.textblock: Retrospective review of de-identified hospital emergency room and trauma registry data and operating room case logs from April 9th through June 9th, 2016, 2017 examining outcomes as affected by a ransomware attack in a level I trauma center

detailed_description.textblock:
On April 9, 2017, Erie County Medical Center, Western New York's sole level I trauma center was under cyberattack. The perpetrators utilized ransomware that gained access to the hospital's web server and encrypted hospital data, forcing a system-wide downtime for nearly 2 months. Electronic medical records, imaging, and interdepartmental communication were severely affected, forcing the hospital to temporarily return to pre-EMR era operations. We examined the impact of this cyber disaster on the outcomes of trauma care.
Retrospective review of de-identified hospital emergency room and trauma registry data and operating room case logs from April 9th through June 9th, 2016, 2017, and 2018. Baseline characteristics of study cohort for each period will be examined using the chi-square test for categorical variables and the Student's t-test for continuous variables that are normally distributed.
This was an exempt study in our institution.

primary_outcome.measure: Hospital and ICU length of stay (LOS), and in-hospital mortality
primary_outcome.description: Hospital and ICU length of stay (LOS) in days And in-hospital mortality between cohorts expressed as percentage of cohort

secondary_outcome.measure: Disposition at discharge and AHRQ patient safety indicators: DVT/PE, CLABSI, CAUTI, and organ/space surgical infection.
secondary_outcome.description: Disposition at discharge defined as either discharged home, died, or sent to a rehabilitation facility, all expressed as the proportion of the cohort group with the above-mentioned findings reported in percentages All AHRQ patient safety indicators: DVT/PE, CLABSI, CAUTI, and organ/space surgical infection are indicated as the proportion of the cohort group with the above-mentioned findings reported in percentages

study_pop.textblock: Trauma patients being served by the level I trauma center catchment area in Western New York, Southern Ontario (Canada), and Northern Pennsylvania

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- All trauma patient admissions that were seen through the ECMC Trauma Center from April to June 2016 and April to June 2017
- Adult patients >13 years old
Exclusion Criteria:
-Patients who came through the emergency department that were not categorized as trauma patients

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: State University of New York at Buffalo
responsible_party.investigator_title: Clinical Instructor and General Surgery Resident, Department of Surgery
